Award.AwardTitle: Building High-Performance Perpetual Wireless Sensor Networks Through Mobile Energy Replenishment

Division.LongName: Div Of Electrical, Commun & Cyber Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
The objective of this project is to develop a novel framework for wireless sensor networks which exploits a joint design of the latest wireless power transfer technology with mobility to achieve high performance with low system cost and maintain perpetual operation of the network.

Intellectual merit:
The intellectual merit is to adopt the latest wireless power transfer, controlled mobility for energy replenishment and data gathering techniques in wireless rechargeable sensor networks. This research develops a novel integrated approach to addressing several closely coupled issues: (1) Efficient and scalable energy information collection; (2) Energy replenishment and energy-aware data collection; (3) Sensor-mission assignment with quality assurance. This project develops a new class of algorithms that improve data throughput, network utility, surveillance quality, and most importantly, guarantee the perpetual operation of network. The proposed work combines protocol design, algorithm design, probability modeling, combinatorial optimizations, software simulations and testbed implementations to conduct a full-scale study on the above issues.

Broader impacts:
The broader impacts are to provide a new paradigm to reliably power wireless sensor networks which is transformative to conventional sensor networks. This project would be beneficial to a wide spectrum of applications, including military, environmental, health care, target tracking and commercial business areas. The important findings of this project will be disseminated to the research community by ways of conferences, journals, and web site access, and to the industry by facilitating the partnership between the industry and the academia through New York State Center of Excellence in Wireless and Information Technology.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project builds a high-performance wireless sensor network that can work perpetually by utilizing the novel wireless charging technology. Wireless sensor networks organize autonomous sensors to capture data from the physical environment such as temperature, weight or motion. Traditionally, sensors are powered by batteries so their lifetime is limited and the network is restrained from performing many high-rate data services. The latest breakthrough in wireless charging has enabled a new dimension to power sensor nodes perpetually through a mobile actuator. Sensor batteries can be recharged conveniently over distance by a mobile actuator without wires or plugs. How to integrate this novel technology to revolutionize traditional designs is the core of the problem. Our project focuses on solving this fundamental problem so that our approaches can be implemented towards many practical applications.

Real-time energy information collection. We develop a framework based on the latest Named-Data Networking (NDN) paradigms that one or more vehicles can collect real-time energy information in the sensor network with low overhead. The framework involves a hierarchical structure naturally utilizes mechanism in NDN to enable query and message delivery from anywhere in the sensing field. An efficient algorithm is proposed to minimize the moving cost of the vehicles and guarantee recharge before sensor's battery depletion. A theoretical model that calculates the number of vehicles needed to cover the number of sensor nodes is established.

Combine data collection and wireless charging. We study the problem to combine data collection and charging on a single vehicle. This design symbolizes high spatial-temporal efficiencies but requires much effort to solve many conflicting problems. We formulate the problem into an optimization problem that maximizes utility from all sensors. Many practical constraints such as battery capacity, vehicle's tour length, packet latency, recharging time, and wireless link status are considered.

Practical constraints. We study the recharging schedule that maximizes the recharging profit - the amount of replenished energy less the cost of vehicle movements - under some important constraints. We derive the minimum number of vehicles needed for energy neutral condition and discover a set of desired network properties. We formulate the recharge schedule optimization into a Profitable Traveling Salesmen Problem with capacity and battery deadline constraints. We provide two algorithms to solve the problem. The first one is a greedy algorithm that maximizes the recharge profit at each step; the second one first adaptively partitions the network based on recharge requests, then forms Capacitated Minimum Spanning Tree in each partition followed by route improvements.

Multi-hop wireless charging. We propose a framework to enable multi-hop wireless charging using resonant repeaters. We present a realistic model that accounts for detailed physical factors to calculate charging efficiencies. To achieve balance between energy efficiency and data latency, we propose a hybrid data gathering strategy that combines static and mobile data gathering to overcome their respective drawbacks and provide theoretical analysis. Then we formulate multi-hop recharge schedule into a bi-objective optimization problem. We propose a two-step approximation algorithm that finds the minimum charging cost and calculates the charging vehicles' moving costs with bounded ratios and a post-optimization algorithm to further improve the results.

Hybrid solar and wireless charging. We propose a hybrid framework that combines solar energy harvesting and wireless charging technologies - cluster heads are equipped with solar panels to scavenge solar energy and the rest of nodes are powered by wireless charging. We study a placement problem on how to deploy solar-powered cluster heads that can minimize overall cost and propose a distributed 1.61(1+\epsilon)^2-approximation algorithm for the placement. We establish an energy balance in the network and explore how to maintain such balance when sunlight is unavailable. We also consider combining wireless charging and mobile data gathering in a tour.

Joint sensor activity schedule and recharging. We consider jointly scheduling sensor activity and recharging to save the traveling energy of mobile charger. We propose two schemes to manage sensor activity: balanced clustering and distributed sensor activation schemes. We introduce a new metric so that the energy demand in each cluster can be managed. Then we formulate the recharging problem into a Traveling Salesman Problem with Profits. For the recharging route schedule, we study a single mobile charger by coordinating sensor activity and energy replenishment, and extend it to multiple chargers. 

K-coverage. We relax the strictness of perpetual operation by allowing some sensors to temporarily run out of energy while still maintaining target k-coverage in the network at lower cost of mobile charger (MC). We establish a theoretical model to analyze the performance improvements under this new strategy. We organize sensors into load-balanced clusters for target monitoring by a distributed algorithm. We propose a charging algorithm to determine the optimal number of sensors to be charged in each cluster to maintain k-coverage and derive the route for MC. We further generalize the algorithm to encompass mobile targets.
